posts.raw_content:
The term "Spiral Case" (Danish: Spiralsagen; Greenlandic: Spiralit) refers to a, major, painful historical scandal in Greenland from the mid-1960s to the 1990s, where Danish health authorities fitted thousands of Greenlandic Inuit women and girls—some as young as 12—with intrauterine devices (IUDs), or "coils," often without their knowledge or consent. 
The initiative was part of a state-directed population control campaign designed to reduce the high birth rate among the Indigenous population and lower social costs for Denmark.

The Copenhagen Post 

Mette Frederiksen Denmark's PM:
August 28, 2025  ·
"We recognise that the spiral case is a source of both anger and sadness for many Greenlanders and families in Greenland. We cannot change what has happened, but we can take responsibility. Therefore, on behalf of Denmark, I would like to say: sorry,” Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen said in a statement issued yesterday.
This marks the first time Denmark has issued a formal apology for its role in fitting thousands of Inuit women and girls with intrauterine devices (IUDs) as part of a state-directed programme to curb population growth between 1966 and 1975—now referred to as the spiral case. Until now, Denmark had only expressed regret and commissioned investigations.
As part of the programme, an estimated 4,500 IUDs were inserted within the first five years, sometimes in girls as young as 12, and often illegally without their consent. The practice had far-reaching consequences: Greenland’s birth rate halved within a few years, and many affected women suffered lasting health problems and infertility.
Alongside Frederiksen, Greenlandic Premier Jens-Frederik Nielsen also issued an apology on behalf of the Government of Greenland for the harm and abuse inflicted on women after Greenland assumed responsibility for its healthcare system in 1992. “I apologise to those of you who have been subjected to—and lived with the consequences of—interventions you did not ask for or control,” he said.
In addition to apologising for Denmark’s role in the spiral case, Frederiksen acknowledged the state’s broader responsibility for failing to stop the systematic discrimination of Greenlanders over the years.
posts.author: JamesBlomey
posts.title: Did you know Greenlander girls as young as 12 were sterilized by Denmark just to cut costs? Turns out low birth rates save the government money!
posts.content:
The term "Spiral Case" (Danish: Spiralsagen; Greenlandic: Spiralit) refers to a, major, painful historical scandal in Greenland from the mid-1960s to the 1990s, where Danish health authorities fitted thousands of Greenlandic Inuit women and girls—some as young as 12—with intrauterine devices (IUDs), or "coils," often without their knowledge or consent. The initiative was part of a state-directed population control campaign designed to reduce the high birth rate among the Indigenous population and lower social costs for Denmark.

The Copenhagen Post

Mette Frederiksen Denmark's PM: August 28, 2025 · "We recognise that the spiral case is a source of both anger and sadness for many Greenlanders and families in Greenland. We cannot change what has happened, but we can take responsibility. Therefore, on behalf of Denmark, I would like to say: sorry,” Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen said in a statement issued yesterday. This marks the first time Denmark has issued a formal apology for its role in fitting thousands of Inuit women and girls with intrauterine devices (IUDs) as part of a state-directed programme to curb population growth between 1966 and 1975—now referred to as the spiral case. Until now, Denmark had only expressed regret and commissioned investigations. As part of the programme, an estimated 4,500 IUDs were inserted within the first five years, sometimes in girls as young as 12, and often illegally without their consent. The practice had far-reaching consequences: Greenland’s birth rate halved within a few years, and many affected women suffered lasting health problems and infertility. Alongside Frederiksen, Greenlandic Premier Jens-Frederik Nielsen also issued an apology on behalf of the Government of Greenland for the harm and abuse inflicted on women after Greenland assumed responsibility for its healthcare system in 1992. “I apologise to those of you who have been subjected to—and lived with the consequences of—interventions you did not ask for or control,” he said. In addition to apologising for Denmark’s role in the spiral case, Frederiksen acknowledged the state’s broader responsibility for failing to stop the systematic discrimination of Greenlanders over the years.
